original: Ekman, Carl-Axel, förste flygläkare, flottiljläkare v. Östgöta flygflottilj, Lin|köping, f. 14/1/01 i Liund’ av toMi-uppsyniman Axel E. o. Bothilda Al-fons. G. 34 m. Karin Nyländer. Barn: Bengt f. 42. — Studiex. i Malmö 20, med. kand. i Lund 26 o. med. lic. där 32. E. läk. v. kir. klin. i Lund 28, assist :läk. v. Landskrona las. 32, dito o. tredje und :läk. v. Malmö allm. sjukh. kir. avd. 33, tf. andre und:läk. där 33-34, und :läk. v. Kullbergska las. 34-37, därund. uppr. förordn. s. över-läk., tf. stads- o. sjukhusläk. i Arboga 37, uppr. förordn. s. stadsläk. i Linköp. 38-46, järnv:läk. å linjen Linköp.-Bjärka Säby-Åtvidaberg sed. 44. Marinläk :stip. över stat 29, dito i res. 31-35, v. Mlk 35, marinläk. av 2 gr. 36, flygläk. av 1. gr. 37, förste flygläk. sed. 42, kommend. s. fartygs- o. fäst-n:läk. 30-37. RVO.
translated: Ekman, Carl-Axel, first flight surgeon, squadron physician at the Östgöta Air Force Wing in Linköping, born January 14, 1901 in Liund, son of inspector Axel E. and Bothilda Al-fons. Married to Karin Nyländer in 1934, with a son named Bengt, born in 1942. He completed his baccalaureate in Malmö in 1920, became a medical candidate at Lund University in 1926, and received his medical license there in 1932. Ekman worked as a medical intern at the surgical clinic in Lund in 1928, assisted as a medical intern at Landskrona Hospital in 1932, worked as a third and acting second medical intern at the surgical department of Malmö's general hospital in 1933, and served as a medical intern at Kullberg Hospital from 1934 to 1937. He was temporarily appointed as chief physician and acting municipal doctor in Arboga in 1937, temporarily appointed as municipal doctor in Linköping from 1938 to 1946, and has served as a railway doctor on the Linköping-Bjärka Säby-Åtvidaberg line since 1944. Ekman was awarded with the Royal Order of the Vasa. He was also a naval medical stipendiate from the state in 1929, served in reserves from 1931 to 1935, became a military physician in 1935, became a flight surgeon in 1937, then became a first flight surgeon in 1942. He served as commander for ship and fortress physicians from 1930 to 1937.
